titleInfo.title: Development of Methods for Improving the Accuracy of Density Functional Theory Simulations

mods:mods.abstract: Improving the accuracy and efficiency of methods has always been the pursuit of scientific computing. In this dissertation, we developed several methods to improve the computational efficiency and accuracy of Kohn-Sham density functional theory (KS-DFT) and orbital-free density functional theory (OF-DFT). Random-phase approximation (RPA) correlation functional greatly improved the accuracy of KS-DFT and has gained much attention. For example, RPA correlation energy gives more accurate lattice parameters and atomization energies of solids, producing reasonable phase transition pressure for the $\alpha$-$\gamma$ transition of cerium, and much-improved adsorption energies of CO molecule on various transition metal surfaces. In Chapter 2, we developed a stochastic method, based on the kernel polynomial method (KPM), to calculate the RPA correlation energy. To accelerate the sampling efficiency, we introduced an atom-based correlated sampling (ACS) scheme to accelerate the convergence of the energy-difference calculations of two similar systems. Our method may be applied to calculate the adsorption energies of molecules on transition metal surfaces in the future. OF-DFT is a promising tool for large-scale metal simulations. Its accuracy is determined by two factors: (a) the quality of the kinetic energy density functional (KEDF) and (b) the quality of the local pseudopotentials (LPSs). Compared to simple metals, it is challenging to develop reliable KEDFs and LPSs for transitional metals due to the localized d electrons. In Chapter 3, we built high-quality LPSs for both main-group and transition metals by letting the LPSs reproduce the atomic orbital energies and orbitals (beyond certain radii). For the magnetic systems (Fe, Co, and Ni), our LPSs are also required to reproduce the energy difference between the high-spin and non-spin atomic states. Our LPSs were tested against the projector augmented wave (PAW) and the all-electron (AE) results by calculating various phases' lattice constants, bulk moduli, and energies. Our LPSs agree well with the PAW and AE results in most cases. Lastly, we collaborated with Prof. Biwu Ma's group at the Florida State University to study the absorption and emission spectra of various binuclear platinum (II) complexes. Linear-response time-dependent density functional theory (LR-TDDFT) was used to explain the photophysical results of these complexes with various Pt-Pt interactions. It was found that strong Pt-Pt interactions lead to pronounced metal-to-ligand charge transfer absorptions in the lowest energy peaks (between 450 nm to 500 nm).
